awd_titl_txt: Documentation and acquisition of Light Warlpiri and Warlpiri
awd_abstract_narration:
In most endangered language situations, speakers transition from speaking an endangered language to an existing majority language. In very rare situations, children learning both an endangered language and a majority language may create a new mixed linguistic variety with features of both languages. These unusual situations provide clues to social, psychological and linguistic mechanisms involved in the emergence of such novel communicative forms.

Linguist Carmel O'Shannessy of the University of Michigan will document a newly emerging language, Light Warlpiri, in a small indigenous community in northern Australia, focusing on the role of children and young adults in the development of the language. Light Warlpiri is a mixed language using Warlpiri, English, and Northern Territory Kriol (a local English-based creole). Although Light Warlpiri has recently emerged and is still stabilizing, it is also highly endangered.

Three striking features of Light Warlpiri make its documentation at this point in time especially important. First, the oldest speakers of Light Warlpiri are only about 35 years old, so relative to how long languages can exist, Light Warlpiri is young and can be observed as it grows. Second, the structure of Light Warlpiri is unusual - the verb structure is from varieties of English and Kriol, but with some radical innovations, and the noun structure - word endings - are from the traditional language, Warlpiri. Third, children learn both Light Warlpiri and the traditional language, Warlpiri, which is an uncommon language learning situation.

Through audio and video recordings of staged and spontaneous language contexts, the project will track children's acquisition of Warlpiri and Light Warlpiri, providing insights into bilingual acquisition in a complex linguistic context, as well as insights into the interaction of language endangerment and language emergence. The project will add audio and video time-aligned data to an existing longitudinal corpus which was started in 2002, forming an open-access audio-visual corpus of children's and adults' language spanning approximately 15 years. The corpus will be used to produce a sketch grammar of Light Warlpiri, tracing the sources of grammatical features. The project will also create online activities in Warlpiri which Warlpiri youth and young adults can access from their cell phones, promoting Warlpiri maintenance and engagement with technology.

por.por_cntn:
This project has taken steps to document the role of children and young adults in a newly emerging mixed language, Light Warlpiri, spoken by about 300 Warlpiri people in Lajamanu, a remote Indigenous community in northern Australia. This kind of documentation of a language so early in its life is something that linguists are rarely able to do. Further, most of the work on how young children acquire their languages is on major world languages, with very little on minority languages. This project makes a valuable contribution to the work on child language acquisition and new language emergence in an endangered languages context. 

      Light Warlpiri is a systematic combination of elements of Warlpiri and varieties of English and/or Kriol (an English-lexicon Creole). Most of the noun structure is from Warlpiri, but most of the verb structure is from English and/or Kriol, with radical innovations. Other lexical elements are from either language. The project has contributed to documentation of the roles of children and young adults in the development of Light Warlpiri, and simultaneously the maintenance of their traditional language, Warlpiri. 

The project has contributed approximately 30 hours of audio and video time-aligned, transcribed and morphosyntactically glossed data to an existing longitudinal corpus which began in 2002, forming an open-access audio-visual corpus of children’s and adults’ language spanning approximately 18 years.

The project has produced many journal articles and book chapters in three main areas:  a) the grammar of Light Warlpiri, tracing the sources of grammatical features, with comparison where relevant to the relevant Australian languages, Kriol and Warlpiri, b) processes of language maintenance and shift, investigating children’s acquisition, and c) has developed an empirically-based model of how a new contact language emerges.

      Mixed languages, by definition, have a structure in which elements of two (or more) source languages are combined systematically, and they are few in number. This project addressed intriguing questions about the ways in which source languages can be combined in a mixed language. The data show that rather than leading to simplification, this type of language mixing can lead to greater complexity in a subsystem within a language. Study of the perception and production of the sound system of Light Warlpiri, specifically of plosives (e.g. p/b, t/d, k/g), shows that the speakers of this language have amalgamated parts of the sound systems of the source languages into a single, larger system with more distinctions than any of the source languages has. The study of fricative sounds (e.g. f/v, s/z, sh) shows that again the speakers have amalgamated parts of the systems of the source languages, and in this case show considerable influence from one source, English, over another source, Kriol. Interestingly, the multilingual speakers of Light Warlpiri do not show influence of other languages in the sound system of Warlpiri when they speak it – they produce Warlpiri sounds the same way that older speakers of Warlpiri do. This is especially interesting as it suggests that these speakers show clear continuation of transmission of the Warlpiri sound system, and clear separation in their use of their two main languages. 

      The reflexive and reciprocal system (e.g. ways of saying ‘myself’, ‘each other’) of Light Warlpiri is particularly interesting. The system draws on English and Warlpiri very clearly, by having words such as maiselp ‘myself’, yuselp‘yourself’, from English, but using the same words for reciprocal constructions, as Warlpiri does. The speakers bring complex verbs from Warlpiri ,which has quite a different verbal structure, into Light Warlpiri, and integrate the  verbs into Light Warlpiri structure, showing fluid movement between their two systems. The importance of these and other findings is that grammatical patterns in this young, newly developing language show both great systematicity and conventionalisation at an early stage of the life of the language, and also great creativity by the speakers, who often do not copy attributes from the source languages, but re-analyse them to create entirely new systems. The roles of children versus adults in these processes has been investigated, with the finding that the two age groups each lead change in different parts of the grammar. 

The project has made an important contribution to linguistic typology, by providing details of the grammatical and sound systems of a less-common type of mixed language, with unique properties. This contributes to our understandings of linguistic universals and constraints. It has also added to the typological work on Warlpiri in terms of the phonology. The project has increased our understandings of a multilingual acquisition context about which little is known, specifically the role of children in language maintenance and new language development and stabilization. It has increased our understandings of psycholinguistic processes involved in such a situation, and the sociolinguistic contexts that enable an emerging code to continue being spoken, while its speakers also learn and speak their traditional language.
